title: 114_hr3718
content: The Act titled "Preventing and Reducing Improper Medicare and Medicaid Expenditures to Restore Integrity to Benefits Act of 2015" aims to strengthen Medicaid program integrity by providing flexibility in funding allocation and necessary adjustments determined by the Secretary to carry out the Program. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHING MEDICARE ADMINISTRATIVE CONTRACTOR ERROR REDUCTION INCENTIVES. Section 1874A(b)(1)(D) of the Social Security Act is amended to include incentives for Medicare administrative contractors to reduce improper payment error rates. The Social Security Act is amended to provide incentives for Medicare administrative contractors to reduce improper payment error rates, which may include a sliding scale of award fee payments and additional incentives for achieving specific goals determined by the Secretary. This could involve substantial reductions in award fee payments under certain contracts. The Social Security Act is amended to incentivize Medicare administrative contractors to reduce improper payment rates by implementing specific goals determined by the Secretary. The amendments will apply to new contracts three years after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will apply incentives to Medicare contractors through contract modifications, not subject to the Act's effective date. SEC. 4. Strengthens penalties for illegal distribution of Medicare, Medicaid, or CHIP beneficiary identification or billing privileges by imposing up to 10 years imprisonment or a fine of up to $500,000 ($1,000,000 for corporations). SEC. 5. Improves data sharing between the federal government and state Medicaid programs. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish a plan to enhance State participation in the Medicare-Medicaid Data Match Program. Amendments are made to improve the program's effectiveness in reviewing claims data and identifying providers, services, time, and patients. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will enhance State participation in the Medicare-Medicaid Data Match Program by improving the program's effectiveness in reviewing claims data and identifying providers, services, time, and patients. This includes investigating and recovering amounts related to suspect claims and developing an automated data system architecture for program integrity and oversight. The Secretary will develop a plan for States to access data on improper payments made for healthcare services to dual eligible individuals under the Medicare program. In this section, a dual eligible individual is defined as someone entitled to benefits under Medicare Part A or Part B and eligible for medical assistance under a State plan or waiver. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 18 months of this Act's enactment on the implementation of the provisions and amendments outlined in this Act and the Medicare Access and CHIP Reauthorization Act of 2015.
